message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has type 2 diabetes mellitus, a 10-kg weight gain over 3 years, and significant central obesity, indicating insulin resistance as the most important factor in the development of his hypertension. The other options may contribute to hypertension, but are not the primary factor in this patient’s case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s BMI and significant central obesity suggest that he has insulin resistance, which is the most important factor in the development of his condition. Accumulation of fat in visceral tissue can lead to insulin resistance, but it is a consequence rather than a cause of the condition. Release of proinflammatory cytokines may contribute to insulin resistance, but it is not the most important factor. Increased dietary salt intake may contribute to hypertension, but it is not the underlying cause of the patient’s condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s medical history, weight gain, and diabetes suggest insulin resistance. Central obesity is also a symptom of insulin resistance. Other factors, such as proinflammatory cytokines and dietary salt intake, may contribute to hypertension, but insulin resistance is the most important factor in the development of the patient’s condition. Accumulation of fat in visceral tissue is also a symptom of insulin resistance.

The patient's history and physical exam findings suggest metabolic syndrome, which includes central obesity, hypertension, dyslipidemia, and insulin resistance. Insulin resistance is the most important factor in the development of this patient's condition.

Central obesity is also a significant risk factor for hypertension. While proinflammatory cytokines and dietary salt intake can contribute to hypertension, insulin resistance is the most important factor in the development of this patient's condition.

Insulin resistance is likely the most important factor in the development of his hypertension. While release of proinflammatory cytokines and accumulation of fat in visceral tissue are also contributing factors, they are not the most important in this particular case. Insulin resistance can lead to an accumulation of fat in visceral tissue and release of proinflammatory cytokines, but the primary factor is the resistance to insulin. Increased dietary salt intake can contribute to hypertension, but it is not the most important factor in this patient's condition.

The patient's history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and significant central obesity are indicative of insulin resistance, which is the most important factor in the development of his condition. Visceral adipose tissue accumulation and salt intake can contribute to hypertension, but insulin resistance is the underlying cause. Proinflammatory cytokines also play a role in the pathogenesis of hypertension, but insulin resistance precedes their release.

The patient's history of type 2 diabetes mellitus, weight gain, and high blood pressure indicate insulin resistance, which is the most important factor in the development of this patient's condition. While factors such as proinflammatory cytokines and dietary salt intake can contribute to high blood pressure, accumulation of fat in visceral tissue is also a consequence of insulin resistance rather than a cause.
